Hi, I'm Anna Marie Cox and welcome to Conspiracy Month on With Friends Like These. There is an
obvious reason why a political podcast might want to be talking about conspiracies for a month.
And that's because we have a conspiracist in chief in the White House. We have a hospital
foreign power that weaponized conspiracy theories and a presidential election. We have
conspiracy theories breaking through into real life with people taking weapons into a piece of
parlor to try and save the children they think are being enslaved there. Those are all really
good reasons to be talking about conspiracy theories in this day and age. There's another good reason
that might be less obvious. And that's that conspiracy theories are actually kind of normal.
The more you learn about them as a phenomenon, the more you realize that, well, everyone believes
in a conspiracy of some kind, although they may not think of it as a conspiracy theory. And also,
you begin to realize that some of the conspiracies are true. One person's like fantastic idea
is another person's history lesson. You may scoff at a Tea Party Patriots idea that the
government is going to put dissenters into FEMA camps, but the American government has put plenty
of people into camps. They're putting some people in camps right now. And how different is the idea
that they're putting something in the water from the decades of experimentation on people of color
that basically created modern medicine? A conspiracy theory can be the expression of anxiety by a
person afraid of losing power, and they can be a description of how the powerful protect themselves.
So our goal this month is not to point and laugh, though there will be some pointing and
probably some laughing. It is to understand conspiracy theories. What are the conditions that
prime people to believe in conspiracies? Why do certain kinds of conspiracy theories flourish?
What can we learn about the truth from lies? So that is all this month, and it starts this week
with two guests. Jesse Walker is the books editor at Reason Magazine, and he's also the author of
The United States of paranoia, which is about the history of conspiracy theories in the US.
And also this week, friend of the pod Parker Malloy, editor at large for Media Matters for America,
and an expert on, well, the real conspiracy against trans people. Coming right up, Jesse and Parker.
Jesse, welcome to the show. Oh, thanks for having me. I am excited to talk to you. I followed your
work for a long time on Reason and in general, also about conspiracies. I consider you something
of an expert on the subject. And my first question is something. Maybe I should say an expert. You are
an expert. And I guess my first question is just an overarching one, which is how did you get started
reporting on conspiracy theories? Like, what is there something that happened? Is there a
particular thing that sparked your interest? Well, I was interested in them before I was any
kind of reporter. So it was always something I was just kind of paying attention to in one way or
another. I mean, it goes back to high school. And I don't know if you want me to get into
biographical details of me discovering conspiracy books on the shelves of the local libraries and
all. But it was already something I sort of had my eye on. And I guess I first wrote about it in
the mid 90s. I mean, the around the time of the Oklahoma City bombing and there was a lot of
media interest in the topic. And I say the first time, I'm sure I wrote some articles that touched
on it previous to that in a book review or something. But I mean, certainly the earliest quotes in
the United States of paranoia that come from my own interviews are from like magazine writing.
I was doing back around 1995, 96, and was still drawing on more than almost two decades later
when I was writing the book. So I gave you a chronological answer. I guess I didn't really
answer the underlying question though. Like, how did I find this interesting? Yeah, you know, I mean,
American culture, I mean, both in the present and American history, I mean, it's not just the
events that happen. It's all the things that people are imagining happening, you know, and
you can give fair, I mean, obviously there's trouble giving even an objective account of who
did what when. But you know, it's at least possible to conceive of doing that with something like,
you know, World War II, the Great Depression, and so on. But part of the story has to be what all
these different groups of people thought were going on. And all these sort of dueling,
you know, I don't want to just say mythologies because that makes it sound like it's all fictional.
And in a lot of what people think are going on, I'm not just saying about conspiracies here,
is just, you know, the perceptions of the world and their expectations. And also, you know, what
it enforces, they see work whether they're political or spiritual or a number of options. So, I think
that's just part of the story and often gets, you know, felt, you know, and so part of what I was
trying to do with this book was to look at American history through the prism of all these, not just
what was happening, but all these imagined extra activities are happening in people's mind,
especially people's fears, although I do have a chapter here on the Neverland Conspiracies too.
So it's not just fear. We have to, we have to cover that because I think that would,
I think some people might be surprised that the idea of a benevolent conspiracy, except maybe
Santa Claus, I guess that's good, benevolent conspiracy. But let's go back to this idea that
there is like an American story about conspiracy theories. I know a little bit about what you've
written and it is true that basically conspiracies have been a part of American culture, like since
before there was an America. Right, since before it was an independent country. I start, and I
should just say at the beginning, I'm not claiming that America is more prone to conspiracy theories

put it on a scale, but we know about all kinds of conspiracy theories in the Middle East, in Russia,

but once Europeans started showing up here, immediately they started imagining conspiracy

taken advantage of that come up with the conspiracy theories, but rather people that

Almost anyone who's not comatose is capable of believing in conspiracies and probably does so.
You'll see studies that say more than half of Americans believe in at least one conspiracy theory.
And those always understate it because what they really mean is more than half of Americans

And if you copy up and say what conspiracy theories do you believe in, you're still not going to get

It is interesting to me how often it seems like in just the conspiracy theories we're talking about
